title: Charging - negative rods and two grounded spheres

content.question: Two spheres on insulating stands have the same diameter, but are made of different materials. One sphere is a conductor and the other is an insulator. Each sphere is connected to ground by a wire and is initially electrically neutral. As shown in the figure, identical, negatively charged insulating rods are brought equally close to each sphere. How are the net charges <math alttext="Q sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="Q sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>i</mtext></msub></math> on the conducting and insulating spheres, respectively, related when the negatively charged rods are close to the spheres? Assume that the two setups are far enough apart that they do not affect each other.

choices.label: <math alttext="Q sub c is greater than Q sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>i</mtext></msub></math>
<math alttext="Q sub i is greater than Q sub c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>i</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="Q sub c equals, Q sub i, which is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>i</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>

<math alttext="Q sub Q equals Q sub i, which equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mtext>i</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>
